item.title: Body: Inner Layer
item.description:
The body of this guitar will be comprised of three layers of hardwood - an inner core of cherry sandwiched between two outer layers of maple. The maple outer sections have already been prepared so now the focus is on the inner cherry layer.

While preparing the cherry board to be a guitar body, I had to change my approach and do quite a bit extra work to get the wood parts into what I consider a suitable state for an instrument. What follows is the story.

To start with, here was the rough board.

There was some end-checking and cup-warping. This is a very old board. Old wood is good, right? In my optimism, I believed I could work around these defects. The cupping should have been a red flag…

After much planing to remove the cup-warp the board was nice and flat and in good shape to be cut out into the two sides for the guitar body.

then I noticed something…

This board is very flat-sawn, and also has a considerable amount of sap wood (the light area) compared to the heart wood. This explains why it cupped over the years. I was very worried that this grain direction and mix of sap and heartwood would be cause for instability in the finished instrument, causing warping, tuning problems, uneven shrinkage, and eventually cracks.

Ideally, quarter sawn wood is used, where the grain runs vertically instead of side to side like in this flat sawn board.

Waiting for another, more quarter sawn, cherry board this wide to come along would delay this project for years probably.

New Plan

How to turn a flat sawn board into quarter sawn? Cut into strips, turn them 90 degrees, glue together. This will result in a much more stable structure. The downside is it is a lot more work.

Fortunately, there was enough wood in the board to achieve this. To make the guitar shape, not every section needs to be the full length, so some parts of the board can become two or three sections. I planned out the sections on the computer, lettered each section A-N, cut them out, and started the long process of gluing them up.

Once all the strips are cut out, I arranged them according to the body template to get the final plan for joining them together. One good thing is that since the board was already planed flat, the faces to be glues are already mating nicely.

Notice that the innermost strips are maple. This was somewhat unplanned, but the maple top and back pieces are just shy of the necessary width, so I plan to have some narrow strips on the inside to widen the neck area just a bit.

Now for the glueing process, which I did over the course of a few weeks, taking advantage of dry weather when it came. This did require getting some larger clamps.

After some more gluing and planing, the resulting halves are complete.

I also ended up using some strips of walnut on the inside to compensate for lost width due to all the cutting.

The next step will be to cut out the chambers for the electronics and weight reduction, then glue on the top and back maple plates, and finally attach the halves to the neck core to form the final body.

item.title: Headstock Shaping Part 2
item.description:
Now that I have test-fit the tuners, the headstock can be shaped into the final form.

This just required a little work on the disc sander to get the sides flat and converging to the end. And finally rounding off the arrow-head to a smooth point.

I applied a wash coat of shellac to seal and protect the wood for the rest of the build process and to start to get an idea of how finished product will look.

The figure of the tiger maple is starting to pop nicely. This will look nice once it is French polished.

item.title: Bridge Design
item.description:
In this post I will share some of the decision process used to select the type of bridge used on the guitar.

Background

The bridge of a multi-scale guitar needs to accommodate the different string lengths, and cannot simply be perpendicular to the strings like on a normal guitar. More specifically, the saddles themselves are not all the same distance from the nut-end of the neck. For this specific guitar, the bridge-end of the strings form a 14 degree angle.

This requires some special treatment for the builder, since most off-the-shelf bridges will not work. There are a few bridge options that can be purchased, the option of a custom-made bridge, or the option of making my own.

MIDI Guitar

This adds another twist to the thought-process. I have been considering making the guitar a MIDI controller as well. I have been looking into the GraphTech Ghost saddles, which have Piezo transducers embedded within them which allows sending to an acoustic preamp board or a MIDI converter through their “Hexpander” board. GraphTech has a system of modular components that work with these saddles.

Ghost Saddles

These saddles essentially allow you to send a signal for each individual string. The saddles connect to a circuit board in the guitar (the Hexpander) which outputs to a 13-pin MIDI connector jack. The 13-pin connector from the guitar goes to an external MIDI converter which takes the string signals and outputs midi events which are then sent to a synth. The 13-pin is somewhat of a standard, and there are converter units available such as from Roland, Yamaha, and Axon. (None of this is inexpensive.) I believe this GraphTech system is used in the Parker Fly guitars.

Hexpander Kit

I have not fully decided on this route, but it would be nice to have this option later and using an appropriate bridge now will make this much easier.

Requirements

  • Strat-style saddles
  • 14 degree angle

Nice-to-haves:

  • Slot for Piezo wires (Ghost Saddles)
  • Inexpensive

Options

Hipshot Multi Scale Bridge

https://hipshotproducts.com/collections/guitar-bridges/products/6-string-multi-scale-fixed-guitar-bridge

This was my initial first choice when planning the guitar project.

It comes in 11 degree option which is not exactly the 14 I need, but it would be close enough.

Pros

  • Seems like a solid, well-made bridge
  • Low risk of making a bad choice

Cons

  • Somewhat expensive, just over $100
  • Does not have slots for Piezo wires, would need to modify
  • Would require additional cost to upgrade to Ghost saddles

Hipshot Solo Bridges

https://hipshotproducts.com/collections/guitar-bridges/products/solo-single-string-guitar-bridge

With these, you buy one for each string and position them individually on the guitar according to the spacing and angle required.

Pros

  • Can be mounted to form any custom angle
  • Built-in slots for Piezo wires
  • Grooves for height-adjustment screws seems like a nice detail
  • Supports top-loaded strings in addition to body-through (cool, although unneeded)
  • Can be purchased individually

Cons

  • Expensive. $25 to $30 EACH. (But again, I could by them one-by-one over a few months and spread the cost out)
  • Would require additional cost to upgrade to Ghost saddles

Overall, I think is the best option, barring the cost.

Other Off-The-Shelf Options

There are a few other multi-scale bridge solutions available to buy. I am ruling them all out due to their cost and other various reasons why I do not like them.

ABM Single Bridge

https://abm-guitarpartsshop.com/ABM-GUITAR-PARTS/Single-Bridges/Guitar/ABM-3210/ABM-3210b-Black::229.html

Guyker Headless Guitar Bridges

https://www.guyker.com/products/guyker-wt003-cnc-aluminum-alloy-headless-guitar-bridge-with-brass-saddles

Musiclily

https://www.amazon.com/Musiclily-Non-tremolo-Individual-Separable-6-Saddle/dp/B0CCS3WG2G

DIY Bridge

It seems feasible that I could make my own simple bridge from brass bar/sheet stock. I could color it black using Birchwood-Casey Brass Black.

I would need to buy the saddles, though, but could get the Ghost saddles right away, or could start with GraphTech string-savers and upgrade to Ghosts later.

Pros

  • Lower cost
  • Will be at correct angle
  • Full control of design / can be as simple as needed
  • Can use whichever saddles I want without having to “buy” extra that come with an premade bridge

Cons

  • Probably will not look as clean as a machined bridge
  • More risk in mistakes
  • Potential downside of making unconventional holes/routes into the guitar body that would not be compatible or covered by another type of bridge if I ended up buying.

V1

Here is my first go at a design. It is basically two pieces. One is a 1/4 inch thick brass bar that the saddles screw into. I am thinking it can be partially embedded into a routed slot in the guitar body. The other piece is a 1/8 thick brass plate for the saddles to rest on.

The main gist of this design is that the holes for the saddle screws are drilled at the required 14 degree angle, and slightly countersunk on both sides for the screw-head and spring to sit into.

I thought about trying to replicate the design of the HipShot Solo saddles. This seems to require a bend or removing a lot of metal to get the right-angle shape. I am not an metal expert, but believe bending 1/8 thick brass is a no-go unless it is anealed. I am not skilled in this practice so am ruling it out. In short I do not think the HipShot Solo bridge is a feasible design for me to produce.

V2

I soon realized that I could use individual saddle mounts instead of a single solid bar. Some 1/4 inch round brass rod with a hole through the side might work.

3/8 rod would probably be better. In addition to the hole for the saddle screw, the ends of the hole will need to be drilled wider for the screw head and spring.

Top view showing hole-through, with ends drilled wider:

All that remains now is some brass plate for the height adjustment screws to bear upon. This does not need to be a single piece either. Some small, minimal plates might work, if they could be attached cleanly.

Barrel Nuts

There are actually pre-made hardware objects that are almost exactly to this spec. They come in black, too. I have not been able to find the exact size needed though.

https://www.amazon.com/Mardatt-Barrel-Zinc-Plated-Slotted-Furniture/dp/B0FBFTLKY1

I have also seen these nuts in an “offset” version where the hole is closer to one end, almost just like my design. If I could find these in black, it might be ideal.

Incidentally, I used one of these to attach the mortise-and-tenon neck on my Super K guitar (Ã  la Cumpiano). These furniture fasteners seem to keep coming up.

Custom Made Bridge

Another option is to design my own bridge, or individual parts, but get SendCutSend to make them for me. I have used them before for an acrylic fret spacing template and they provide a great service at very reasonable prices.

Pros

  • Can get the exact design I want
  • Can use whichever saddles I want without having to buy extra

Cons

  • Requires learning how to 3D-CAD an object (this could be considered a pro actually)
  • Most likely prohibitively expensive

item.title: Tuner Holes
item.description:
The tuners have arrived. Now I can finally determine the exact position of the tuners and the holes in the headstock. I like to do this operation with the actual tuners on hand. All bought parts and hardware should be obtained before starting the build, but I could not wait.

These came directly from Sperzel in Ohio. I really like their locking tuners. I am also a fan of the 12:1 ratio. Most quality tuners are 16:1 or more these days, marketed as being more precise. It is true you can turn them more and get less pitch change which is supposed to make tuning easier. I find that with the high ratio tuners I get annoyed having to turn them so much. I prefer 14:1 or 12:1. They are touchier of course but any guitar player should have no problem using them.

I also really like their pin-mount system. No screws needed.

And made in the USA!

The thumbwheel on the back locks the string into the post hole, so no extra wraps are needed.

As an aside, Sperzel is an odd company to do business with. Their tuners are not available from any retail vendor currently, so they must be purchased either from individuals on eBay or Reverb (usually at a markup) or from Sperzel directly. The nice folks at Sperzel do have a website but no online ordering capability or even reliable email correspondence, so orders must be placed by calling them. And then there is no way to check order status or shipment tracking. This is my second time going through this disconcerting process but both times it has worked out great.

Getting the positions of the tuners correct took some careful planning and measuring. I mapped out the positions in Libre Office and printed out a cardstock template which I used to mark the locations of the pilot holes for the tuner posts. Then the pin mount holes were located using a little clear acrylic jig I made that ensures all 6 tuners stay in a line and do not end up looking crooked and out of place. (Jigs specially made just for this purpose can be bought for $30-40 but I like doing things the hard, i.e. cheap, way.)

Next a #36 drill bit was used to drill the pin mount holes. Then the tuner post holes were drilled out with a 3/8 forstener bit, and reamed ever so slightly to the required 13/32 diameter.

This was pretty nerve wracking, though. I was worried I would get something out of line. But with a test-fitting, I think it looks pretty good.

Now that I know exactly where the tuning machines will be, the final shape of the headstock can be carved out.

item.title: Kent Rehab
item.description:
This cool 1960s Kent came around again. It is an unusual hollowbody made in Japan, probably by Teisco. This time it was buzzing and ratting around the bridge.

Getting to the rattle took some lengthy diagnostics, and I ended up taking it apart to isolate the noise. I believe the rattles and buzzes were possibly coming from multiple sources.

  • The pickup mounting springs (notorious offenders)
  • Some wood chips, dust, and debris bouncing around inside
  • Screws and roller wheels in the bridge itself

Note the two bridge-mounting holes. They are NOT placed at the nominal scale-length location but are about a three-eighths of an inch shy, which is weird. More on this to come…

Bridges

This guitar was found by its owner with a wooden archtop guitar bridge which slid around and was generally useless. Someone put this there probably temporarily to get it semi-playable. Any use of the tremelo would pull the bridge (and loose nut) out way out of alignment. About 10 years ago I replaced it with a metal roller-type bridge, thinking it would work better with the tremelo. This was an improvement, but still not ideal since it was a bit too thick and still did not line up with the mounting holes.

Here is the (non)original bridge, and the replacement roller bridge.

A new, more vintage-correct and shallower bridge is needed. Stay tuned.

Frets

Aside from a new bridge, what this guitar really needed was a refret. The first five frets were quite worn and buzzing out. There was some metal left, and I could have tried to simply level and crown these, but the result might have been frets much too low. With consent of the owner, the decision was made go all the way and do a full refret. I happened to have a bunch of 55x110 jumbo fret wire on hand, which should really be a huge improvement in playability.

Old frets removed.

New frets installed.

I have been practicing the semi-hemispherical fret ends, which are shaped prior to pressing the frets in. I think it makes for a very smooth feel and looks cool, too. No more sharp edges.

New Bridge

Thanks to eBay, a “Vintage Japanese style Super Low Profile Chrome Guitar Bridge” can easily be obtained from EZPZ Parts out of Washington state. The metal bushings that came with it are too big for the mounting holes on the guitar, though. Plus putting the bridge directly over the holes would position the bridge too close to the nut and too short for the scale length of the guitar.

I will need to fabricate a new base that fits the holes but positions the bridge a bit back from the holes.

Step 1 is to get the bottom surface contour to match the arched top of the guitar. I have a decent little scrap of rosewood which seems appropriate and fits nicely after some sanding.

After reducing the thickness down to where good action will be in range, and adding the mouning posts it is ready for final positioning. I glued some 7/16 dowel pieces to the bottom which fit into the mounting holes, but positioned forward so the intonation point of the bridge is back where it needs to be. The metal screw posts are actually at the far back end of the holes in the guitar body, which is about right in this case.

Scale Length

This guitar has an odd scale length. It is 640 mm, or 25.19685 inches. My theory is that the guitar was intended to have a 25 or 25.5 inch scale length, and the bridge mounting holes in the body were drilled accordingly. But the fretboard uses a zero-fret, which moves (and shortens in this case) the intonation points. A manufacturing snafu? Who knows. I do like having a zero-fret though, which is common on these Japanese guitars. It makes the action at the nut really easy to get perfect.

New bridge is now in good working order, in the right spot, and stays put. I like this bridge because it is a low profile, and is adjustable both side to side and up and down.

New Nut

The nut itself is not super important on a zero-fret guitar, as the main function is only to control the string spacing. The intonation point and string-height is taken care of the by the zero-fret. However, this old tusq job is looking rough, a bit shallow, and is not quite spaced right anyway. Time for a new bone nut.

The new bone nut shined up and spaced correctly looks way classier.

Pickup Mounting

I replace all pickup mounting springs with lengths of surgical tubing nowadays. This eliminates the buzzing and rattling and general odd vibrations caused by springs.

Before:

After:

While at it, I also cleaned up some old wiring inside.

New Year, New Life for Kent

Sounds and plays great now!

item.title: Headstock Shaping Part 1
item.description:
Made some progress on the headstock. The edges were cut out on the bandsaw and disk sanded flat. Then the neck “flare-outs” shaped on the spindle sander.

Now for the fun part - carving the stair-step edge with a paring chisel.

Fine, hand-worked details like this are what separate one-off artisan-made guitars from what typically comes from a factory.

Still some more to go. The cherry edge on the right needs to be brought in quite a bit to make a smooth point with the other pieces. Then the tip rounded will be rounded off. Overall looking good.

item.title: Backstrap
item.description:
This was unplanned, but I decided the headstock needed a backstrap.

After having added the headplate I noticed two things:

  1. The headstock was too thick by about 1/16 inch
  2. The headstock had a bit more flex than I would prefer

The extra thickness could have easily been solved by sanding the backside down. But that would exacerbate the flex problem. I decided to solve both these headstock issues in the following manner:

  1. Plane off 1/8 of an inch from the back
  2. Lay in some carbon fiber reinforcement
  3. Add a 1/16 thick veneer over the back, extending slightly into the neck area (commonly known as a “backstrap”)

The result will be a headstock that is 1/16 thinner than before but a lot stiffer.

So this meant going back to the Safe-T-Planer to trim down, slicing out another veneer of walnut, and repeating the glue down process used on the headplate. (The backstrap will only be 1 layer thick.)

Inlaying Carbon Fiber Bars

The backstrap iteself will add a good deal of stiffness, but I figured why not go the extra mile and add in some carbon fiber to make it even stiffer. I happened to have a 4 inch piece leftover from a previous guitar that had a shorter neck.

As an aside, here is a good methodology. I wish I had figured this out and used this method for the carbon fiber bars I have already glued into the neck. I will know better next time.

First, the bar is CA-glued top-down to a sheet of approx 1/8 thick spruce. I had some offcut from an acoustic guitar top that is perfect.

This is trimmed out so that the top of the bar has a spruce extension strip.

The channel is routed to a depth approx 1/16 deeper than the carbon fiber itself, so that only the spruce extension comes up proud. (The end of this channel is a little sloppy. I really should have done all routing before adding the ears.)

Now while gluing, the spruce strip on top provides something for the clamps to press on.

Then the extra spruce is planed off, leaving only a nice wood surface.

This is ideal because the carbon fiber is protected from being scaped, planed, or sanded now. It should not be cut or worked at all, really, for safety reasons.

Backstrap Installed

Now with the backstrap glued down, the headstock is the perfect 9/16 thick and it feels MUCH stiffer.

Here I have traced the outline of the headstock template upside down to show approximately where the cutout will be. Note the rounded area where the headstock meets the neck. This little rounded section will extend into the neck just past the 0-fret line. Much of this end will be trimmed off and shaped during neck-carving, but I wanted to get that rounded part pre-shaped at this stage.

NOW the headstock is ready to be trimmed out.

item.title: Wiring Diagram
item.description:
Here is a drawing of the planned wiring scheme. This is not a true schematic, but a simple diagram of the components and their connections. At this point the emphasis is on the switches to make sure the functionality I want will be possible. So far so good.

This is also not laid out according to where the components will be on the guitar yet. It is just to get an idea of the circuit and the connections.

For the 2-pole on/on switches, the vertical gray bars represent the connections that get made when switch is thrown. They are shown in the above diagram in the “Down” position, where the connections are from lugs 5 to 6 and 2 to 3. When in the “Up” position the connections are 5-4 and 1-2.

The on/off/on toggle is going to be interesting. I am planning on using a standard three-position toggle switch like in a Gibson two-pickup guitar. These switches are actually on/on/on, and the middle position will place the two pickups in parallel. I really want these in series, though. So I may need to use a different kind of switch, or possibly modify the Gibson-type to be on/off/on. Apparently this is possible with the Switchcraft switches which can be taken apart (since they are assembled with screws) and put back together as on/off/on by flipping the contacts around.

item.title: Headplate
item.description:
The headplate on this guitar will be 1/8 inch thick made up of two layers of 1/16 inch veneers - walnut with curly-maple on top. The first step is to slice out the veneers. The curly-maple is from the same board as the body of the guitar (recall the extra third section that was fortunately not needed) so should match nicely.

Thickness Sanding

Next they are sanded close to their final thickness on the spindle sander.

They are approximately 3/16 inch thick now but need to be 1/16.

I will stop at around .070 or just a bit more than 1/16.

The final thickness comes after some more sanding with a random orbit sander, and then hand sanding. To make this easier, I use double-sided tape to hold them down to a board that is clamped to the bench.

After sanding, they total about 1/8 of an inch which is the target thickness of the headplate.

Bending

Since this guitar has a radiused end where the fretboard meets the headstock (Fender style) the headplate will be bent to accommodate this curve. The plates, even though only 1/16 inch thick, are not this flexible at all so will need to be heat-bent to shape first.

This is done by wetting the veneer with water and then bending over a hot pipe (around 350-400 degrees) to the necessary curve . Then they are held down to where they need to go to dry and cool using the spindle as a mold. This is basically the same way I bend hollowbody guitar sides, which I can hopefully cover in more detail in the future.

Now they are thicknessed and bent and ready to glue down.

Gluing

Once correctly positioned, I use two small drill bits as index-pins in the waste areas to lock down the location and keep it from sliding around during gluing.

Special top and bottom cauls and multiple clamps to apply pressure. Again, hot hide glue is used for this.

The walnut layer glued down first.

Then then maple layer glued on top.

Clean up and trim

To wrap up this stage, the overhang where the fretboard meets the headstock is trimmed back flush to the neck. This trimmed end will be covered by the end of the fretboard when it is attached later.

Now we can see how the final shape of the headstock will be cut out (note light pencil lines) and where the holes for the tuners will go. I might make some final adjustments here, but this is pretty close to the final shape.

item.title: Electronics Plan V1
item.description:
Some cold weather today so I am staying out of the shop and taking a closer look at the electronics planned for the guitar. Once the guitar is fully assembled and strung up for the first time (before finishing, though) I will see what it sounds like and test out different circuits and components using an external breadboard before drilling the final holes for the potentiometers (pots) and switches.

Initial Idea

Pickup Selector Toggle

This is a Les Paul style three-position toggle for the neck pickup, bridge pickup, or both in parallel. Black. I considered other options such as individual on/off switches for each pickup or a Telecaster-style blade pickup, but landed on the toggle with the idea that it is the most fool-proof way to easily flip while playing. The exact placement will be determined once I actually try to play the guitar to see where my hand goes when moving my elbow to get it in just the right spot. I will also angle switch movement so as not to make it too easy to flip to avoid accidentally switching it during vigorous strumming.

Neck and Bridge Tap Switches

These will be mini on/on toggle switches to control the pickup taps. The plan is to use Seymour Duncan Quarter Pound Strat Tapped pickups, which have a normal, modern high-output lead plus an additional tapped lead for a more vintage half-power output. This will allow the player to get two different sounds out of each pickup. I expect the normal (up) position will be more suitable for modern high-gain styles and the tapped (down) will produce more a traditional clean/jangly strat-type sound.

Tone ByPass

Mini on/on toggle that will allow bypassing the tone circuit completely. When down, the normal tone and volume signal path is active. When switched up, the tone controls are bypassed and have no effect, so only the volume control is in the circuit. The thinking is that tone controls do attenuate the signal even when turned all the way up, because the resistance of the pots is not infinite and some signal is still getting grounded. Add in the capacitors, and there is tone being changed even when the tone is on “10”. So this allows the player to get an even more pure and raw signal from the pickups without any influence by the tone controls. Only the volume control still works.

Tone Knob 1 - Bass Cut

This is a bit different from a normal single-tone control on a guitar. This guitar will have separate treble and bass controls (passive). This is directly copying the G&L S500 wiring. Most guitars just have a single tone control which attenuates the high frequencies. Here with the additional bass-frequency attenuation, the player will be able to clean up the signal to cut through a mix better by cutting out some bass. This will be a 1MG Ohm audio taper pot, with a small capacitor around 1000 picofarads. When testing the circuit I will determine the best capacitor value. Black, 20mm aluminum knobs for the tone controls.

Tone Knob 2 - Treble Cut

This is the more traditional tone control that just cuts the high end. I am thinking 500k audio-taper pot, with a .022 microfarad capacitor. Again, will experiment to find a good sounding capacitor.

Volume

Basic volume control. 250k linear pot. I prefer linear pots for volume, as opposed to audio-taper. Note the large knob… I am thinking of using freakishly large 32mm knob for the volume to allow the player to easily grab it with their pinky finger while playing to do dramatic volume swells.

Direct Out

One last on/on toggle switch near the volume, which will bypass both the volume and tone from the circuit and send the pickup signal directly to the jack. This is for an even more pure, raw signal unaffected by any pots or capacitors. This can act as a mini “boost” effect during a performance. Used this way, it is sometimes called a blower switch. It might also be useful for recording, where all tone and volume is controlled during mixing and you want the purest and loudest signal to be recorded.

Jack

I am thinking of trying one of these PureTone jacks. In black of course to match all the other hardware. The jack will be in the side of guitar, Telecaster style, using a nice recessed plate.

Breadboarding

What I usually do is mount the pickups into the guitar and connect the leads to a breadboard tester on my desk, which is then connected to an amp. The allows me to fiddle around with different components and wiring schemes before soldering anything.

More photos and updates to come on this subject.
